Dietary data annotation

University of Barcelona, Spain.
polcaes@gmail.com

dietary_data_annotation.Rmd

Compiled date: 2021-01-16

Last edited: 2021-01-14

License: GPL-3

Installation

Run the following code to install the Bioconductor version of the package.

# install.packages("BiocManager")
BiocManager::install("fobitools")

Load fobitools 

library(fobitools)

You can also load some additional packages that will be very useful in this vignette.

library(dplyr)
library(kableExtra)

Create an example dietary free-text data

In nutritional studies, dietary data are usually collected by using different questionnaires such as FFQs (food frequency questionnaires) or 24h-DRs (24 hours dietary recall). Commonly, the text collected in these questionnaires require a manual pre-processing step before being analyzed.

Here is a small example of what a 24h DR could look like in a nutritional study.

# create a dummy dietary data
free_text <- tibble(id = c(101, 102, 103, 104),
                    text = c("Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea", 
                             "Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain", 
                             "Beef and veal, one apple", "pizza without meat"))
id text
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea
102 Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain
103 Beef and veal, one apple
104 pizza without meat

Automatic anotation with fobitools::annotate_foods()

The annotate_foods function allows the automatic annotation of free nutritional text using the FOBI ontology. This function returns a table with the IDs and names of the FOBI terms that match the input text.

The annotate_foods function provides a text mining algorithm composed of 5 sequential layers. In this process, singulars and plurals are analyzed, irrelevant words are removed, each string of the text input is tokenized and each word is analyzed independently, and the semantic similarity between input text and FOBI’s text is computed. Finally, along with the table the function also returns the percentage of the annotated input text.

annotated_text <- fobitools::annotate_foods(free_text)
#> 100% annotated
#> 5.567 sec elapsed
FOOD_ID FOOD_NAME FOBI_ID FOBI_NAME
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea FOODON:00001061 bacon food product
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea FOODON:03310351 butter
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea FOODON:00001274 egg food product
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea FOODON:00001138 tea based beverage product
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea FOODON:03315081 tea food product
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea FOODON:03306255 toast
101 Yesterday I ate eggs and bacon with a butter toast and black tea FOBI:07511 whole toast
102 Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain FOODON:00001183 bread food product
102 Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain FOODON:00002711 cracker
102 Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain FOBI:07522 crisp
102 Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain FOODON:03301641 rice grain food product
102 Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain FOBI:07510 whole bread
102 Crisp bread and rice crackers with wholegrain FOBI:0148 wholegrain
103 Beef and veal, one apple FOODON:00002473 apple (whole)
103 Beef and veal, one apple FOODON:00001041 beef food product
103 Beef and veal, one apple FOODON:00003083 veal
104 pizza without meat FOBI:007956 vegetarian pizza

Network visualization of the annotated terms

Then, with the fobi_graph function we can visualize the annotated terms with their corresponding FOBI relationships.

terms <- annotated_text$annotated %>% 
  pull(FOBI_ID)

# create the associated graph
fobitools::fobi_graph(terms = terms, 
                      get = "anc",
                      labels = TRUE,
                      legend = TRUE)
